Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and tenant’s remedies)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in leases and tenancies.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.raw_text: Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (discussing warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment)
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in leases and tenancies.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is part of California landlord‑tenant law and explains that the constructive eviction doctrine arose as an expansion of that covenant from protecting mere possession to protecting beneficial enjoyment of the premises. Although the case’s main holding is about an implied warranty of habitability, it expressly treats the covenant of quiet enjoyment as an existing, implied lease covenant whose scope had been judicially expanded. This directly supports the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in leases and tenancies.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: Thus, for example, the doctrine of “constructive eviction,” which expanded the traditional “covenant of quiet enjoyment” from simply a guarantee of the tenant’s possession of the premises (see Connor v. Bernheimer (N.Y. Com. Pleas 1875) 6 Daly 295, 299; Gorgeous v. Lewis (1912) 20 Cal.App. 255, 258 [128 P. 768]) to a protection of his “beneficial enjoyment” of the premises through the maintenance of basic, necessary services (Groh v. Kover’s Bull Pen, Inc. (1963) 221 Cal.App.2d 611, 614 [34 Cal.Rptr. 637]; Sierad v. Lilly (1962) 204 Cal.App.2d 770, 773 [22 Cal.Rptr. 580])…

Brown v. Southall Realty Co., 538 F.2d 1.raw_text: Brown v. Southall Realty Co., 538 F.2d 1034 (D.C. Cir. 1976) (discussing tenant remedies for uninhabitable conditions)*
Brown v. Southall Realty Co., 538 F.2d 1.proposition: *Plaintiff cites the above authorities as representative of the governing legal principles regarding habitability, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and landlord duties to remedy health-hazardous conditions (including mold and inadequate ventilation).

Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1 (Vt. 199.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1 (Vt. 1993) (recognizing landlord obligations and tenant remedies for housing habitability defects)*
Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1 (Vt. 199.proposition: *Plaintiff cites the above authorities as representative of the governing legal principles regarding habitability, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and landlord duties to remedy health-hazardous conditions (including mold and inadequate ventilation).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1 (Vt. 199.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns First Amendment limits on injunctions against residential picketing and the distinction between content-neutral time, place, and manner restrictions and impermissible content-based restraints. It does not address landlord–tenant law, habitability standards, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, or landlord duties regarding health hazards such as mold or inadequate ventilation. Therefore it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 624 A.2d 1 (Vt. 199.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that paragraph one of the restraining order is a constitutional place and manner restriction on defendants focused residential picketing... We conclude that paragraphs two and three of the restraining order are not content or viewpoint neutral. Content-based restrictions are presumptively invalid... and are almost always impermissible in a public forum.... We reverse paragraphs two and three of the injunction for the reasons stated in our recent opinion in Horizon Health Ctr. v. Felicissimo....

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 (Public Health).proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations address sanitary and habitability standards for residential dwellings and vest local boards of health and the Department of Public Health with authority to enforce minimum standards.
